bestBHT.bht: In the morning, the whole council convened, summoning all attendees to this compulsory meeting of accuracy. They bound Jesus once again, preparing a concerted plan of action and delivering him to the Roman governor to carry out his death sentence for the charges of sedition and being an enemy to Caesar. This morning council, mentioned in Luke 22:66-71 and Luke 23:1, was instrumental in the process of sending Jesus to Pilate.

Henry Alford: the whole council is a touch of accuracy.
From ch. xiv. 53 we know that all were assembled.
when all were specially summoned, attendance was compulsory.
Albert Barnes: See the principal events in this chapter explained in the notes at Matthew 27:0.
Philip Schaff: Mark 15:1. The whole council. Comp. Luke 22:66-71, where the particulars of this morning meeting are given; also Luke 23:1.
Archibald T. Robertson: In the morning (πρω). The ratification meeting after day.
Held a consultation (συμβουλιον ποιησαντες)...the idea would be rather to prepare a concerted plan of action.
Bound Jesus (δησαντες τον Ιησουν). He was bound on his arrest and now he is bound again as he is sent to Pilate.
John Gill: And straightway in the morning,.... As soon as it was break of day, or daylight appeared..."
The result of which was, to bind Jesus, and deliver him up to the Roman governor, to be put to death by him, as a seditious person, and an enemy to Caesar..."
The Syriac and Persic versions add, 'the governor'

bhtAttempts.bht: In the morning, the whole council convened, summoning all attendees to this compulsory meeting of accuracy. They bound Jesus once again, preparing a concerted plan of action and delivering him to the Roman governor to carry out his death sentence for the charges of sedition and being an enemy to Caesar. This morning council, mentioned in Luke 22:66-71 and Luke 23:1, was instrumental in the process of sending Jesus to Pilate.

At daybreak, the entire council gathered, summoning all present to ensure accuracy. Bound once again, Jesus was prepared for his transfer to the Roman governor to face the penalty for his alleged seditious acts and perceived threat to Caesar. This morning meeting, described in Luke 22:66-71 and Luke 23:1, played a crucial role in the process of sending Jesus to Pilate.

In the morning, the whole council assembled for a touch of accuracy, with attendance being compulsory since all were specially summoned. The purpose was to hold a consultation and prepare a concerted plan of action before the ratification meeting after day. As a result, Jesus was bound once again and sent to Pilate, the Roman governor, to be put to death as a seditious person and an enemy to Caesar. This decisive meeting, mentioned in Luke 22:66-71 and Luke 23:1, held significant weight in the process of Jesus' journey to Pilate.
